posts.cooked: I am working on a project to build my own FRC bot, and I was wondering what would be a good charger for just a few battery‚Äôs at a time

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: Basically any automatic battery charger for 12v lead acid batteries will work, just make sure the charge current doesn‚Äôt exceed 6a (max charge rate for our batteries)

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked:
Hard to beat the Dual Pro RS series chargers. I‚Äôve used these before, and they work well, but take a little longer https://www.costco.com/duracell-4-amp-battery-charger-and-maintainer.product.100479359.html

I‚Äôve also thought this would be a good budget option. https://www.harborfreight.com/4-amp-fully-automatic-microprocessor-controlled-battery-chargermaintainer-63350.html

posts.name: Mr V
posts.cooked:
Define ‚Äúfew‚Äù batteries and the other question is how fast do you need to be able to use them again?

If you are going to have multiple chargers and don‚Äôt require them to be available as quick as possible this is a good choice.

https://www.homedepot.com/p/Schumacher-Electric-Schumacher-Pro-Automotive-6-Volt-12-Volt-2-Amp-Battery-Charger-and-Maintainer-with-Auto-Voltage-Detection-SPR1627/317443390#overlay

https://www.homedepot.com/p/Schumacher-Electric-6-Volt-or-12-Volt-2-Amp-Automotive-Battery-Charger-BE01248/207123536

Both are proper maintainers that will switch to float mode when the battery is fully charged and it comes with a disconnect in the output cables and multiple connection options so easy to put the Anderson connector on the ones with the ring terminals and still have the clamps to use on a car battery. Plus it is from a brand with a good reputation at a reasonable price. Yes it will take longer than a 6A charger but not 3x as long since that 6A charger will spend a lot of time only putting out 2A or so.

If you really need it as soon as possible and you can afford to spend a little more then I‚Äôd go with this. https://www.homedepot.com/p/Schumacher-Electric-6-Amp-6-Volt-12-Volt-Charger-Maintainer-SC1320/315434901 Again a trusted brand and a decent price.

posts.name: Petra Lear
posts.cooked: Like four total, but probobly only need to charge two batteries at a time

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked: We‚Äôve bought several of the Noco Gen5x1 and been happy with them so far.  Small, reasonably priced, 5A with ‚Äúsmart‚Äù charging features.  We haven‚Äôt had good luck with the DualPro (we have two of the 3-channel ones and both have issues).

posts.name: Ender Wiggin
posts.cooked:
Not sure why you would bother with an FRC battery if you were not constrained by the rules. I would just pick up a Hobby lipo battery and charger. There are inexpensive ones all over amazon.

Let's talk about Li-ion Batteries in FRC Electrical

posts.name: Petra Lear
posts.cooked: mainly because i am thinking of donating it to my team when i am done with it. but thanks for the suggestion!

And if this is just a home project and you‚Äôre not going to need to rush to recharge batteries like you would at a competition, then you can charge the batteries at 2a and 4a (we charge ours at 4a). It‚Äôll help make sure your batteries last longer.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
1293 has six of these chargers that @AllenGregoryIV put us onto in late 2019.  $50, compact enough that having six isn‚Äôt a big deal, good indicators (we did tape over the markings above the lights since the two battery-shaped diagrams made it harder to glance at), and the only failures we‚Äôve had with them since putting them into service were where the SB50 connector pulled out‚Äìentirely our fault since it doesn‚Äôt ship with them installed.

We also own the Dual Pro RS3 like many others, and we‚Äôre happy with it too.
